Companies.description: The Companies table stores information about each company using the system. It serves as the primary reference table, as most other tables are linked to a company through CompanyId. This table helps keep data organized and separate for each company. It contains essential company details, such as the company name, contact information, and subscription

columns.description: A unique, auto-incremented identifier that serves as the primary key for each company (tenant). It is used to distinguish and isolate data for each tenant, ensuring that a company can access only its own data.
A flag indicating whether the company is integrated with QuickBooks. When set to true, the company is connected to QuickBooks. when false or null, the company is not integrated.

The IsQBSync flag shows whether the record is synced from QuickBooks . If it’s true, the data is synced; if it’s false or null, the data is not synced with QuickBooks. This represents wether data is downloaded from QuickBooks to Upvoit or not.
This column defines the tax calculation order — whether the discount is applied before tax (Position 1) or after tax (Position 2).

The TimeZone value refers to the ID from the Timezone table, which defines the company’s default timezone. It linked with table called "Timezone" and Column is "Id". User this relation to build a join to retrive timezone
The CompanyName is the official name of the company as it will appear in the system and reports.
This columns represent/stores address 1 line for company's business address.
This columns represent/stores address line 2 for company's business address.

State/Province of the company’s address
Postal/ZIP code for the company’s address

Official company email address

Default currency for the company (linked from Currency table).

users.description: The Users table stores information about all individuals who interact with the system, including employees, administrators, and contractors. Each user is associated with a record in the Company table. The table includes fields for personal information (name, email, phone, address) and login details (email, password).

columns.description: Primary key (unique identifier for the user).

This column stores the user’s first name.

This column stores the province or state of the user’s primary address.
This column stores the zipcode or postal code of the user’s primary address.

It is a reference to the "Countries" table, column "CountryId". Use this relation to build joins and retrieve country details.

Boolean flag indicating if the user is a contractor.

Stores the URL/path to the user’s profile image.
Represents the labor cost associated with the user.

companyUsers.description: The CompanyUsers table defines the relationship between companies and users, indicating which employees, administrators, or contractors belong to each company. This table is especially useful in systems that support multiple companies and users, as it enables efficient management and tracking of users within their respective organizations. Additionally, the CompanyUsers table stores user-specific details per company, such as work information and rate details used for payroll and invoicing purposes.

This Colummn Indicate the userId linked with table called "Users" and column name "UserID". Use this connection for getting CompanyWise user

Identifies the main contractor associated with a subcontractor. Any user with a ContractorId is considered a subcontractor. In processes such as payroll, the contractor appears as the primary user, with the subcontractor displayed as a child user under them.
This columns stores ClientId/ClientContactId when allow client and client contact person login.
Information about the user’s device (for login/security tracking).

Clients.description: The Clients table stores information about customers or organizations that a company works with. It keeps details like client names, addresses, and related business data. This table helps companies manage their customer relationships by keeping all client information in one place. It is the starting point for linking to jobs, invoices, quotations, requests, and other activities related to a client

clientProperty.description: The ClientProperty table stores details about properties or locations linked to a client. For example, a client may have multiple offices, or sites where jobs and services are performed. This table helps companies manage work at specific client locations by keeping property-related details (like address or site info) separate from the main client record.

countries.description: The Countries table stores a list of countries along with their details such as country name, code, mobile code, and currency. It is mainly used to link users, clients,ClientProperty, and companies to their country, for address management and currency handling.

columns.description: Primary key (unique identifier for each country).
Full name of the country (e.g., United States, India).
Standard ISO country code (e.g., US, IN).
Indicates whether the country is active and available in the system.
References the Currency table (CurrencyId column), which defines the default currency for the country. Use this relationship to create joins for retrieving currency details.
Country dialing code (e.g., +1, +91).

checkList.description: The CheckList table stores predefined lists of tasks, steps, or items that need to be completed as part of a job, visit, or project. It serves as the master record for checklist templates used across the system.

columns.description: Unique identifier for the Cehcklist Master.
Reference to the company the checklist belongs to. It linked with table called "Company" and column is "CompanyID". Use this relationship to build a join to retrieve Company name
Name of the checklist (e.g., "Pre-Job Safety", "End-of-Day Cleaning").
Date and time when the checklist was created.
User who created the checklist.
Date and time when the checklist was last modified.
User who last modified the checklist.
Soft-delete flag (1 = deleted, 0 = active).
Defines the sequencing logic for checklist items. For example, 0 = Flexible (items can be completed in any order), and 1 = Sequential (items must be completed in a specific order).

checkListDetails.description: The CheckListDetails table stores the individual items or tasks that belong to a checklist. Each record represents a single step (like  Check equipment, Take photos,  or  Get client signature ) that is part of a larger checklist. It helps break down a checklist into detailed actions so they can be tracked and completed one by one.

columns.description: Primary key (unique identifier for the checklist detail).
Reference to the company the checklist belongs to. It linked with table called "Company" and column is "CompanyID". Use this relationship to build a join to retrieve Company name
Reference to the parent checklist. It is linked with table called "CheckList" and column is "Id". User this connection to build a join to retrive Checklisdetails.
The actual checklist item or step text (e.g., "Wear safety helmet", "Take before photo").
Date and time when the detail was created.
User who created the detail.
Date and time when the detail was last modified.
User who last modified the detail.
Soft-delete flag (1 = deleted, 0 = active).
Defines the display sequence of the detail within the checklist.

documentCategory.description: The DocumentCategory table is used to group company documents into categories

columns.description: Primary key. Unique identifier for the document category.
Name of the document category (e.g., "HR", "Finance", "Legal", "Safety").
Reference to the company this category belongs to (ensures each company can maintain its own set of categories).

documentSubCategory.description: The DocumentSubCategory table is used to create sub-categories under a main document category. Each sub-category is linked to a company and a document category, making it easier to organize documents in a more detailed way (for example, under  Financial  →  Invoices ,  Receipts ).

columns.description: Primary key. Unique identifier for each document subcategory.
Name of the subcategory (e.g., "Contracts", "Agreements", "Invoices").
Reference to the company that owns this subcategory. It's refrenced by table called "Company" column "CompanyId". Use this connection to build join to retrieve subcategory data based on the company

groups subcategories under a parent category. It's refrenced by table called "DocumentCategory" column "CategoryId". Use this connection to build join to retrieve subcategory data based on the Category

companyDocument.description: The CompanyDocument table stores all the important files and documents related to a company. Each record represents one uploaded document (like licenses, contracts, policies, or certificates) that belongs to a company. Document uploaded by category and sub-category. Also Document type is defined as a Private document or a public Document.

columns.description: Primary key (unique identifier for the document).

Type of document ( Public Document = 1,
 Private Docuemnt = 2,)
This column represent categoryId. refrence by table "DocumentCategory" column "CategoryId". Use this connection to build join with category
This column represent SubCategory Id. refrence by table "DocumentSubCategory" column "SubCategoryId". Use this connection to build join with category
Human-readable name/title of the document.
Description or notes about the document’s content.
Storage URL or path of the uploaded document.
Date & time when the document record was created.
UserId of the person who uploaded/created the document.
Date & time of the last update.
UserId of the person who last updated the record.
Soft-delete flag (true if the document is deleted/archived).
Reference to the company that owns the document. Refrenced by table called "Company" column named "CompanyId" Use this to build join with company wise data
Original filename of the uploaded file.
File size in KB/MB for reference.

currency.description: The Currency table stores information about different currencies, including their name, code, and symbol.It is mainly used to support financial transactions, invoicing, and international payments by linking to countries and companies.

columns.description: Primary key (unique identifier for each currency).
Full name of the currency (e.g., US Dollar, Indian Rupee)
Standard ISO currency code (e.g., USD, INR).
Symbol of the currency (e.g., $, ₹).

docNumbers.description: The DocNumbers table is used to manage document numbering for different records (like invoices, jobs, or quotes). It helps keep documents organized by storing the next number, prefix, suffix, and formatting rules for each company.

columns.description: References the company to which this document numbering rule belongs.
The next sequential number to be used (e.g., if NextNo = 101, the next invoice number will be 101).
A text prefix to prepend to the number (e.g., INV-, JOB-).
A text suffix to append to the number (e.g., -2025).
Code identifying the document type (e.g., INV = Invoice, JOB = Job, QUO = Quotation).
Number of digits for zero-padding. For example, if Padding = 5 and NextNo = 12, the formatted number becomes 00012.

feedback.description: The Feedback table stores different feedback categories created by a company

columns.description: Primary key. Unique identifier for each feedback record.

Reference to the company this feedback belongs to. Ensures multi-company separation. It's refrenced by table called "Company" column "CompanyId". Use this connection to build join to retrieve subcategory data based on the company
Name/title of the feedback (e.g., “Customer Satisfaction Survey”, “Technician Performance Feedback”).
Date and time when the feedback entry was created.
UserId of the person who created the feedback record.
Date and time when the feedback entry was last updated.
UserId of the person who last updated the feedback record.
Soft delete flag (0 = Active, 1 = Deleted) to preserve history while hiding inactive feedback items.

feedbackQuestions.description: The FeedbackQuestions table stores the list of questions linked to a specific feedback category. It allows companies to define what questions will be asked when collecting feedback from clients or technicians.

columns.description: Primary key. Unique identifier for each feedback question.

Reference to the company that owns this feedback question. Ensures multi-company isolation. It's refrenced by table called "Company" column "CompanyId". Use this connection to build join to retrieve subcategory data based on the company

Foreign key to the Feedback table. Groups questions under a specific feedback form/template. This field refrenced to table "Feedback" column name "Id". Use this to build join to retive data by feedback id.
The actual feedback question text (e.g., “How satisfied are you with our service?”).
Date and time when the question was created.
UserId of the user who created the question.
Date and time when the question was last updated.
UserId of the user who last updated the question.
Soft delete flag (0 = Active, 1 = Deleted) to keep history while hiding inactive questions.

feedbackResponse.description: The FeedbackResponse table stores the answers given to feedback questions. It links each response to a job, client, and feedback form, capturing ratings or comments submitted.

columns.description: Primary key. Unique identifier for each feedback response.

Reference to the company that owns this feedback response. It's refrenced by table called "Company" column "CompanyId". Use this connection to build join to retrieve subcategory data based on the company
References the related job, linking feedback to a specific service or job performed. This column references the Job table (Id column) and can be used to create joins for retrieving job-specific data.
References the client who provided the feedback. This column references the Clients table (ClientId column) and can be used to create joins for retrieving client details.
References the feedback entry. This column references the Feedback table (Id column) and can be used to create joins for retrieving feedback data.
Identifies the question for which this response was provided. This column references the FeedbackQuestions table (Id column) and can be used to create joins for question-specific data.
Numeric or scaled rating provided as the answer (e.g., 1–5 stars, or could be adapted for Yes/No).
Date and time when the response was first created.
UserId of the user/system who captured the response.
Date and time when the response was last updated.
UserId of the user who last updated the response.
Flag indicating if the client has fully submitted the feedback. If rating greater than 0 then true else false.
Soft delete flag (0 = Active, 1 = Deleted).

GoogleCalendarCredentials.description: The GoogleCalendarCredentials table stores authentication tokens and related credentials for users who have integrated their accounts with Google Calendar. This allows the system to securely synchronize events and manage calendar data on behalf of the user.

columns.description: Primary key. Unique identifier for the credentials record.
Identifies the user whose Google Calendar is connected. It's refrenced by table called "Users" column "UserId". Use this connection to build join to retrieve form data based on the User
Identifies the company this integration belongs to. It's refrenced by table called "Company" column "CompanyId". Use this connection to build join to retrieve form data based on the company
Token used to access the Google Calendar API (short-lived).
Token used to renew the access token without requiring the user to log in again.

industry.description: The Industry table stores a list of industries (like Construction, IT, Healthcare, etc.) that a company may belong to.

columns.description: Primary key. Unique identifier for each industry.
Name of the industry (e.g., Construction, Healthcare, IT Services).

industryServices.description: The IndustryServices table stores the list of services offered within a specific industry.

columns.description: Primary key. Unique identifier for each service.
Identifies the industry this service belongs to.  It's refrenced by table called "Industry" column "Id". Use this connection to build join to retrieve data based on the Industry
Name of the service (e.g., Plumbing, Roof Repair, IT Support).
Detailed description of the service provided within the industry.
Boolean flag. Marks soft deletion of the service record.

Invoice.description: The Invoice table stores all billing records related to clients, including details such as amounts, taxes, discounts, and status. invoiceAttachment.description: The InvoiceAttachment table stores files or documents related to an invoice, such as receipts, PDFs, or supporting documents.

Reference to the Invoice table to which this attachment belongs. It's refrence by table "Invoice" column "Id", Use this relation to build join to retrive data based on invoice.

invoiceDetails.description: The InvoiceDetails table stores detailed line items for each invoice, including services or products, their quantities, unit prices, and total costs. Each record represents a single item or service on an invoice and includes relevant metadata for tracking and auditing.

columns.description: Primary key (unique identifier for each invoice detail record).
Stores the corresponding line-item ID from QuickBooks (if synced).
References the Invoice table (Id column) to link this detail with its parent invoice. Use this relationship to create joins and retrieve data by invoice.

This table only includes expenses that have already been paid. Each record is associated with a payroll record using the PayrollID.

Set Reminders – to schedule jobs, including recurring reminders. Log Activities – to schedule calls, meetings, tasks, deadlines, emails, or lunches, with associated dates and times.
